name: JavaScript

name: Moq
description: Moq is our default mocking framework and preferred to alternatives such as Rhino Mocks

name: Balsamiq
description: Balsamiq gives us the ability to create quick low-fidelity wireframes to describe workflows

name: OneDrive
description: OneDrive is our default choice for storing Office documents to share within the organization. In the last three years, Microsoft have done a lot of work on OneDrive and the associated sync clients and have closed the gap on their competitors. The sync client is very stable and doesn’t contain the restrictions that it did before.

name: Raygun
description: Raygun allows loosely-coupled error reporting to a web endpoint.

name: Google Drive
description: We don’t have corporate Google accounts and it doesn’t make sense to subscribe to both GSuite and Office 365, both for cost reasons and from an information management point of view. The fact that we don’t have corporate accounts means data can’t be removed from Google accounts when someone leaves the company (as we don’t own the account), so we shouldn’t be storing any personal information (such as customer data) in Google Drive.

name: SmartAssembly
description: SmartAssembly obfuscation and error reporting becomes tightly-coupled to products and slows down builds.

name: Windows
description: Our default supported operating system is Windows. If Microsoft continues to support this as part of their default support package we continue to support running our applications on that OS. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/13853/windows-lifecycle-fact-sheet
